Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a small angle X-ray diffractometer for in situ measurements of liquid to solid samples over a wide range of temperatures
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Description:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) grant will enable the acquisition of a state-of-the-art versatile X-ray diffractometer to fill a critical gap in Lehigh University's microscopy/spectroscopy materials characterization infrastructure enabling unique, comprehensive materials characterization for seamless correlation of material structure and function. The versatility of the instrument for complementary interrogation of a wide range of biological, organic and inorganic sample types should facilitate multi-disciplinary efforts of researchers spanning Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering, Materials Science, Chemistry, Bioengineering, Mechanical Engineering, Earth and Environmental Science, and Physics, among others, and enhance educational opportunities for students. By enabling one-stop materials characterization unique to the region in which Lehigh University is located, the X-ray diffractometer should impact numerous regional start-up companies to well-established industries as well as colleagues at 4 or more local non-PhD granting, but research-active, colleges and universities. The new capabilities for unique and comprehensive insight into materials structure and function will enable a wide range of cutting edge science and engineering aimed at solving Grand Materials Research Challenges within the broad arenas of energy, the environment, and health. Development and deployment of complementary interactive educational X-ray modules will impact domestic and international students enrolled annually in Lehigh?s Microscopy Summer School and a range of middle school, high school, and undergraduate students in educational outreach programs at Lehigh. All of these programs place concerted focus on the recruitment of women, underrepresented minorities, and persons with disabilities.

Technical Description:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) grant will support acquisition of a state-of-the-art, uniquely configured Anton Paar SAXSpace X-ray diffractometer that has simultaneous and continuous small- and wide-angle capabilities and multi-collimated (line, point) X-ray beam configurations suitable for probing even weakly scattering isotropic and anisotropic samples of a wide range of compositions (e.g., solutions, gels, powders, films) and temperatures. Capabilities for in situ tensiometry, grazing incidence small- and moderate wide-angle thin film studies, and biologics analysis uniquely equip this single instrument for comprehensive, non-destructive, and high-resolution multi-scale (i.e., molecular to meso-scale) insight into a diverse range of biological, polymeric and inorganic samples that will augment, integrate and create new, transformative materials analysis distinct from existing state-of-the-art microscopy, spectroscopy, and proximal probe tools at Lehigh. This unique, complementary insight will help establish transformative synthesis-structure-properties relations aimed at efficient and rational materials design. This should enhance active research spanning: (i) Functional, Meso-structured and Meso-porous Inorganic Materials, (ii) Organic, Inorganic, and Hybrid Films, Buried Interfaces, and (iii) Biological and Hybrid Materials, through specific interdisciplinary projects in applications as diverse as catalysts for biomass-to-chemicals conversion, photocatalysts for low-cost liquid fuel production, bioactive glass scaffolding for hard tissue regeneration, mechanics of biomimetic materials and multi-functional nanocomposites, protein and cell membrane phase behavior for biomimetic toxin sensing, and novel therapeutics design, among others.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF-MRI grant enabled the acquisition, installation and commissioning of a state-of-the-art small-angle X-ray scattering instrument (SAXSpace, Anton Paar GmbH) at Lehigh University. The instrument is equipped with simultaneous and continuous wide-angle capabilities and multi-collimated X-ray beam configurations suitable for probing weakly scattering isotropic and anisotropic samples of a wide range of compositions (e.g., solutions, viscous liquids, gels, solids, films) and at temperatures spanning -150oC to 300oC. Specialized analysis is also possible on structured films using a grazing incidence small angle X-ray scattering (GI-SAXS) stage. A tensile stage with interchangeable load cells (5 N, 600 N) enables in situ tensiometry.

The acquisition of the state-of-the-art X-ray diffractometer in this project has established a new and powerful characterization tool at Lehigh that complements existing state-of-the-art microscopy and spectroscopy capabilities on campus. As such, this new instrument has helped to fill a critical characterization gap, and, thus, has played a critical role in establishing Lehigh as a regional center for advanced and comprehensive materials characterization. Since its installation, the instrument has supported research initiatives spanning an interdisciplinary user base comprised of more than 30 faculty, postdoctoral fellows, and both graduate and undergraduate researchers within and outside Lehigh University.

The intellectual merit of this funding includes discoveries and innovations enabled by the instrument primarily in the area of porous and structured materials, and the characterization of nanoparticle solutions. Therein SAXS-based structural characterization has provided key mechanistic understanding into the synthesis-structure-function relations driving the rational design of materials for catalysis, separations, and energy storage (e.g., state-of-the-art supercapacitors) applications. Future studies and an expanded user base are slated in biological and soft matter systems. Data acquired on the instrument have been or are in the process of being disseminated through over 10 journal publications and more than 20 invited or contributed technical presentations at universities, companies, and professional scientific meetings. These technical presentations and additional recruitment efforts have led to numerous industrial collaborations.

The acquisition of the state-of-the-art SAXS instrument has simultaneously established the need and foundation for fundamental and applied training of researchers at Lehigh in materials science and specifically X-ray scattering. The broader impact of the instrument, therefore, is embodied by the education of the user base of 30 faculty, postdoctoral fellows, and both graduate and undergraduate researchers within and outside Lehigh University on fundamentals of X-ray scattering and specific instrument operation. In addition, this funding has initiated a collaborative education-research initiative with a local college in the greater Lehigh Valley revolving around instruction on small-angle X-ray scattering and research involving structural analysis of a tetrameric enzyme as part of an advanced biochemistry course and senior research project. In addition, the acquired instrument has led to the incorporation of concepts of small-angle X-ray scattering in the design of a new advanced undergraduate/graduate elective offered University-wide by the Dept. of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering on Advanced Porous Materials. In combination with general early technical education on small-angle X-ray scattering for a diverse group of potential users across Lehigh?s campus, these targeted educational initiatives have helped this funding impact the education of more than approximately 70 students, faculty, staff, and industrial collaborators.
